titlestmt.titleproper: Preliminary Inventory of the American Educational Research Association Records

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-10-20T12:08-0700

did.abstract: Correspondence, minutes, memoranda, reports, statistics, and sound recordings, relating to education and educational research activities in the United States.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Box 79 may not be used without permission of the American Educational Research Association. Collection is stored off-site. It may be possible to have a limited number of boxes brought to the archives reading room for examination. A minimum of two days notice is required. Please contact the Hoover Institution Archives for further information.

The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives. Box 79 may not be used without permission of the American Educational Research Association.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], American Educational Research Association Records, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

bioghist.head: Administrative History
bioghist.p: American association for the promotion of educational research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, minutes, memoranda, reports, statistics, and sound recordings, relating to education and educational research activities in the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content note
scopecontent.p: In 1990 a congressional staff member, working for the Democratic majority, undertook to design a symposium on effective schools to demonstrate the important contribution of federal funding in stimulating school improvement. A planning committee of education groups was formed, including AERA, papers were written by scholars and practitioners, a conference was held, and a Committee Report was issued.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content note
scopecontent.p: Beginning after the congressional elections in 1994, the Republicans began a concerted effort to eliminate the U.S. Department of Education, which had been established by President Carter. AERA joined forces with a coalition of education organizations to save the department. A comprehensive response was developed which included telemarketing strategies as well as more conventional advocacy tactics. Ultimately, the Republican leadership dropped its plan for a frontal assault on the agency.

did.unittitle: Testimony by staff and association representatives
Creation of the "National Board for Professional Teaching Standards"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content note
scopecontent.p: In the early days of the National Board, AERA was called on for advice about the need for additional research to provide a foundation for the proposed activities, as well as for guidance and support with regard to securing federal funding for this purpose. AERA ultimately supported a sole-source contract and federal funding to the National Board for conducting necessary research and instrument development

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content note
scopecontent.p: In 1983 AERA submitted an "unsolicited grant application" to the Department of Education. The proposal called for bringing together researchers and practitioners to investigate the topic of research contributions to educational improvement.

Files contain individual chapters prepared by selected scholards, a final report to the Department, and a summary authored by George Kaplan (Items for an Agenda: Educational Research and the Reports on Excellence) based on the chapters
